user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of call_connection_handler:
```c
static void
call_connection_handler (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  struct MHD_Daemon *daemon = connection->daemon;
  size_t processed;

  if (NULL != connection->rp.response)
    return;                     /* already queued a response */
  processed = 0;
  connection->rq.client_aware = true;
  connection->in_access_handler = true;
  if (MHD_NO ==
      daemon->default_handler (daemon->default_handler_cls,
                               connection,
                               connection->rq.url,
                               connection->rq.method,
                               connection->rq.version,
                               NULL,
                               &processed,
                               &connection->rq.client_context))
  {
    connection->in_access_handler = false;
    /* serious internal error, close connection */
    CONNECTION_CLOSE_ERROR (connection,
                            _ ("Application reported internal error, " \
                               "closing connection."));
    return;
  }
  connection->in_access_handler = false;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
CONNECTION_CLOSE_ERROR (connection,
                            _ ("Application reported internal error, " \
                               "closing connection."));
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The fragment is a macro invocation only; there is no direct or indirect call to call_connection_handler shown. Therefore Rule 17.2 is not violated in the shown code. A violation would occur only if the CONNECTION_CLOSE_ERROR macro expands to code that (directly or indirectly) re-enters call_connection_handler — for example, if the macro calls a function that queues a response or triggers daemon callbacks which call call_connection_handler. That expansion is not present here, so no violation can be concluded from this fragment.
